items.title: The output of pdf2txt.py has incorrect order of the lines (python2 will generate correct output)
items.body:
**Bug report**

*Reproduction steps*

1. Download the sample pdf: https://github.com/johnlinp/misc-demo/blob/master/pdfminer-six-python-versions/sample.pdf
1. Run `python3 /usr/local/bin/pdf2txt.py sample.pdf`

*Expect result*

In the original PDF file, this paragraph
```
內湖區之住宅區分佈於平緩地區與坡地間，主要沿內湖路、成
功路、民權東路及康寧路兩側分布，其中以第三種住宅區居多，位
於丘陵或坡地部分則為第二種住宅區。 
```
is between the list item `1、住宅區` and `2、商業區`.

Therefore, I expect that the result will be:
```
1、住宅區 
內湖區之住宅區分佈於平緩地區與坡地間，主要沿內湖路、成
功路、民權東路及康寧路兩側分布，其中以第三種住宅區居多，位
於丘陵或坡地部分則為第二種住宅區。 
2、商業區 
```

*Actual result*

The paragraph mentioned above doesn't appear between the list item `1、住宅區` and `2、商業區`.

It shows:
```
內湖區之住宅區分佈於平緩地區與坡地間，主要沿內湖路、成
功路、民權東路及康寧路兩側分布，其中以第三種住宅區居多，位
於丘陵或坡地部分則為第二種住宅區。 
1、住宅區 
2、商業區 
```

*Extra info*

If I run with `python2`, i.e. `python2 /usr/local/bin/pdf2txt.py sample.pdf`, the results will be correct.

Here are the complete results:
1. [Results via python2](https://github.com/johnlinp/misc-demo/blob/master/pdfminer-six-python-versions/results-via-python2.txt)
1. [Results via python3](https://github.com/johnlinp/misc-demo/blob/master/pdfminer-six-python-versions/results-via-python3.txt)

As you can see, the results via python2 is correct.

Therefore, I think it might be a bug since the inconsistency comes from the difference of python versions.

items.title: Removing Pycryptodome Dependency: Massive bloat (extra 260 MB)
items.body:
**Feature request**

Trying to replace PyPDF2 with pdfminer.six for PDF text extraction in an Alpine Linux Python base container (python:alpine3.7) I hit a significant roadblock because of pdfminer's dependency on `pycryptodome`.

Pycryptodome installation requires gcc and a whole load of other dependencies that aren't present in the light base container (90 MB). It took me a while to figure out how to circumvent this problem, which is another reason to try to get rid of the dependency on pycryptodome (https://stackoverflow.com/a/35713086/7483211).

Installation of `apk add gcc g++ make libffi-dev openssl-dev` (requirements for pycryptodome) bloats the image from a mere 90MB to 270 MB.

Then, installing pdfminer.six on top bloats to 351MB. So just for pdfminer.six to be installed almost quadruples storage space.

PyPDF2 didn't really any noticeable extra storage.

I'm not sure what pycryptodome is being used for, if it's not mission-critical, it may be helpful to add it as an optional module, to be installed when actually used, rather than having it ship by default. I guess most people never need it.

I'm also not sure why the pdfminer.six installation is so big itself (seems to be around 80MB in my case). Maybe this can also be optimised further.

from pdfminer.pdfpage import PDFPage
import io

def convert(case, pdfpath, targetfilepath, pages=100):
    if not pages: pagenums = set();
    else:         pagenums = set(pages);
    manager = PDFResourceManager()
    codec = 'utf-8'

    if case == 'HTML':
        output = io.BytesIO()
        converter = HTMLConverter(manager, output, codec=codec, laparams=LAParams())
    if case == 'XML':
        output = io.BytesIO()

    interpreter = PDFPageInterpreter(manager, converter)
    infile = open(pdfpath, 'rb')

    convertedPDF = output.getvalue()

    convertedFile = open(targetfilepath, 'wb')

print(convert('XML', 'sposipromessi3.pdf', 'sposipromessi3.xml', pages=None))

items.title: PDF Text Extraction Results Differ when running pdfminer on Mac vs. Ubuntu
items.body: **Bug report** - I'm using the following function `extract_text_from_report` to extracting text from [this Google Mobility Covid19 Report](https://www.gstatic.com/covid19/mobility/2020-03-29_US_Alabama_Mobility_Report_en.pdf) ```python import io import requests from pdfminer.pdfparser import PDFParser from pdfminer.pdfdocument import PDFDocument from pdfminer.converter import PDFPageAggregator from pdfminer.layout import LAParams, LTTextBox, LTTextLine from pdfminer.pdfinterp import PDFResourceManager, PDFPageInterpreter from pdfminer.pdfpage import PDFPage def extract_text_from_report(url): extracted_text = "" response = requests.get(url) parser = PDFParser(io.BytesIO(response.content)) password = "" document = PDFDocument(parser, password) rsrcmgr = PDFResourceManager() laparams = LAParams() device = PDFPageAggregator(rsrcmgr, laparams=laparams) interpreter = PDFPageInterpreter(rsrcmgr, device) for page in PDFPage.create_pages(document): # As the interpreter processes the page stored in PDFDocument object interpreter.process_page(page) # The device renders the layout from interpreter layout = device.get_result() # Out of the many LT objects within layout, we are interested in LTTextBox # and LTTextLine for lt_obj in layout: if isinstance(lt_obj, LTTextBox) or isinstance(lt_obj, LTTextLine): extracted_text += lt_obj.get_text() return extracted_text ``` - I have code that loads the first page of this report and searches for the string "Parks", in order to get the score that is associated with that field: - When running my script locally on Mac OSX 10.15.3 + Python 3.7.2, the extracted text includes 'Parks'. Parsing the page with `extract_text_from_report` above, I get ``` report_string[1963:2100] --> 'a County\nRetail & recreation\nGrocery & pharmacy\nParks \n*\n-42% compared to baseline\n-8% compared to baseline\n-14% compared to baseline\n' ``` - The bug appears when I run this same code in a Digital Ocean Droplet running Ubuntu and Python 3.7.5. Getting to the same point in my code, and referring to the same original PDF url, when running in the Ubuntu environment, that same page does not appear as having "Parks" in it. Running `extract_text_from_report` in this environment, I get ``` report_string[1963:2100] --> 'a County\nRetail & recreation\nGrocery & pharmacy\n-42% compared to baseline\n-8% compared to baseline\n-14% compared to baseline\n+80%\n+40%' ```

items.title: How to custom newline  (LAparams) when converting to XML?
items.body:
I have this document: https://drive.google.com/file/d/18Kmq4kD2Xai7w9KAROIJZ-6baCKjHA5H/view?usp=sharing

And I converted it in XML with PDFminer. Problem is, I want to have a custom newline every time there are those longer whitspaces, for instance, in the first line, I want to have a newline before the "1" because there is a longer space:

Titolo Il Causidico] sps. a Don Rodrigo [ BIG SPACE ] 1 sventura]sps. a mi-

I tried setting custom LAparams out, but I don't know how to achieve this. My code so far is:

```
from pdfminer.pdfinterp import PDFResourceManager, PDFPageInterpreter
from pdfminer.converter import HTMLConverter,TextConverter,XMLConverter
from pdfminer.layout import LAParams
from pdfminer.pdfpage import PDFPage
import io

def convert(case, pdfpath, targetfilepath, pages=100):
    if not pages: pagenums = set();
    else:         pagenums = set(pages);
    manager = PDFResourceManager()
    codec = 'utf-8'
    caching = True
    word_margin = 1
    laparams2 = LAParams(all_texts=True, detect_vertical=True,
                      line_overlap=0.5, char_margin=1000.0, #set char_margin to a large number
                      line_margin=0.5, word_margin=0.5,
                      boxes_flow=0.5)

    if case == 'text':
        output = io.StringIO()
        converter = TextConverter(manager, output, codec=codec, laparams=LAParams())
    if case == 'HTML':
        output = io.BytesIO()
        converter = HTMLConverter(manager, output, codec=codec, laparams=LAParams())
    if case == 'XML':
        output = io.BytesIO()
        converter = XMLConverter(manager, output, codec=codec, laparams= laparams2)

    interpreter = PDFPageInterpreter(manager, converter)
    infile = open(pdfpath, 'rb')

    for page in PDFPage.get_pages(infile, pagenums,caching=caching, check_extractable=True):
        interpreter.process_page(page)

    convertedPDF = output.getvalue()

    infile.close(); converter.close(); output.close()

    convertedFile = open(targetfilepath, 'wb')
    convertedFile.write(convertedPDF)
    convertedFile.close()

print(convert('XML', 'fel_split2.pdf', 'fe2.xml', pages=None))
```

items.title: Disabling boxes flow makes lines be in wrong order within text boxes
items.body:
**Bug report**

When passing `boxes_flow` as `None`, we don't run the full advanced layout analysis, but rather the order of text boxes will depend on their position on the page only. This is intentional.

If we were passing boxes flow, we'd group the text boxes and then call `analyze` on each group ([here](https://github.com/pdfminer/pdfminer.six/blob/develop/pdfminer/layout.py#L811)). This filters down so that `analyze` is called on the text boxes themselves. When `boxes_flow=None`, we don't call `analyze` on the text boxes, which results in the lines coming in the wrong order as they don't get sorted.

Note that `boxes_flow` is not used in the `analyze` method of text boxes, it is only used for groups of text boxes (which we never have if boxes flow is disabled).

To fix this, we just need to make sure that `analyze` is always called on the text boxes, even if we don't group them.

[Example PDF](https://www.dropbox.com/s/jjhlbsynrnjuq6i/negative_line_margin_example.pdf?dl=0)

Example code:
```
from pdfminer.high_level import extract_pages
from pdfminer.layout import LAParams

la_params = LAParams(boxes_flow=None)

for page in extract_pages("example.pdf", laparams=la_params, caching=False):
    print("*****OUTPUT:*****")
    for element in page:
        print(element)
```

Example output:
```
*****OUTPUT:*****
<LTTextBoxHorizontal(-1) 58.100,343.402,106.178,406.702 'Text 3Text 2Text 1'>
```

Expected output:
```
*****OUTPUT:*****
<LTTextBoxHorizontal(-1) 58.100,343.402,106.178,406.702 'Text 1\nText 2\nText 3\n'>
```

items.title: LAParams boxes_flow documentation inconsistency
items.body:
The documentation for `boxes_flow` of LAParams ([here](https://pdfminersix.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/composable.html#laparams)) reads:
 > Specifies how much a horizontal and vertical position of a text matters when determining the order of text boxes. The value should be within the range of -1.0 (only horizontal position matters) to +1.0 (only vertical position matters).

whereas the code ([here](https://github.com/pdfminer/pdfminer.six/blob/develop/pdfminer/layout.py#L726)) does the following
```
        if -1 <= laparams.boxes_flow and laparams.boxes_flow <= +1 \
                and textboxes:
            # Code to do the full layout analysis, adding groups etc
        else:
            def getkey(box):
                if isinstance(box, LTTextBoxVertical):
                    return (0, -box.x1, box.y0)
                else:
                    return (1, box.y0, box.x0)
            textboxes.sort(key=getkey)
```

From the code, it seems that it is possible to set `boxes_flow` outside the range `[-1.0, 1.0]`. At the moment, any value outside this range will return boxes in an order based on their position. Unfortunately, you can't currently pass `boxes_flow` as `None` because you can't do `None <= 1`. Therefore, to disable this you essentially have to set `boxes_flow` to e.g. `2`.

(Aside: This order is perhaps a bit strange when there are both horizontal and vertical text boxes on the page. I'd be temped to choose a scheme, perhaps depending on if there are more horizontal or vertical boxes on the page, but that's a different issue and probably a breaking change.)

Suggestions:
- The documentation should be updated to explain that this can be disabled.
- I think it would be nicer if the value for "disabled" was `None`, rather than any value in `[-1, 1]`.
- If the valid range is `[-1, 1]` perhaps this should be validated, throwing an exception if this isn't the case.

items.title: Use black for code formatting?
items.body:
Have you considered using [black](https://black.readthedocs.io/en/stable/) for your code formatting?

There are a few drawbacks:
- You'll have one commit which touches almost every file to refactor it to the new styling
- Perhaps you might not like some of the srtyling?

However:
- It's great as a contributor - I don't have to worry about code styling etc, whereas currently I have to infer the styles from the existing code.
- It forces everything to be consistent. I can see that there are lots of existing inconsistencies with e.g. whether you add whitespace around operators.

Happy to discuss further/submit a PR (or obviously just close this issue if you've considered it and decided you don't like it)

items.title: Allow calling high level functions with file-like objects
items.body:
**Feature request**

Some of the functions (`extract_text` and `extract_pages`) in [high_level.py](https://github.com/pdfminer/pdfminer.six/blob/develop/pdfminer/high_level.py) take `pdf_file` as a parameter, the path to the pdf file. This means the PDF file must be on the hard drive.

It would be nicer if there were functions available which allowed any file-like object (like `extract_text_to_fp` does). This means I can still call the functions even if the PDF isn't on my hard drive.

I would guess we don't want breaking changes to the existing functions (?), so will create new `*_from_io` functions, and then the API for the existing ones will be unchanged.

items.title: Allow negative line margin
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

[Example PDF File](https://www.dropbox.com/s/jjhlbsynrnjuq6i/negative_line_margin_example.pdf?dl=0)

In some of the PDFs I deal with, it is possible that the bounding boxes of different lines of text overlap, but I do not want them grouped into one text box. For example, all the text in the example pdf liked above (example code at the bottom) gets grouped into one text box, no matter how small the line margin.

The `line_margin` layout parameter is used to determine how close lines need to be for them to be grouped, but in my case (because they overlap) it is impossible to set it small enough that they don't get grouped.

I appreciate that a `\n` character is added when lines are merged, but I require the structure of your text box elements for my project.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Being able to set a negative `line_margin`, meaning "two lines of text must overlap by at least this value for them to be grouped into one text box" would solve this issue.

In terms of code, we'd adapt [find_neighbors](https://github.com/pdfminer/pdfminer.six/blob/develop/pdfminer/layout.py#L418) to work with a negative `ratio` parameter. I believe the `objs = plane.find(...)` would already work as intended, but we then do other checks of the form `abs(...) < d` which will always be false due to `d` being negative.

I'd be happy to work on a fix, but might need a few pointers about how to adapt these checks for a negative `ratio`. For me, it's not really obvious why we're checking the `height` and `x`-position of the elements based on something related to `line_margin` and `height`... (these checks are also discussed in the additional notes of #382, for a related reason)

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
An alternative would just be to have an option to disable the merging of lines entirely, e.g. you can set `line_margin` to 0 to disable the behaviour. We'd still need to edit to checks as `abs(..)<0` is always `False`, but perhaps `abs(...) <= 0` is acceptable in that case.

**Example code**
```
from pdfminer import converter, pdfdocument, pdfinterp, pdfpage, pdfparser
from pdfminer.layout import LTTextContainer, LAParams
path_to_file = "centered_text_example.pdf"

_LA_PARAMS = LAParams(line_margin=0.00000001)

with open(path_to_file, "rb") as pdf_file:
    parser = pdfparser.PDFParser(pdf_file)
    document = pdfdocument.PDFDocument(parser)
    resource_manager = pdfinterp.PDFResourceManager()
    device = converter.PDFPageAggregator(resource_manager, laparams=_LA_PARAMS)
    interpreter = pdfinterp.PDFPageInterpreter(resource_manager, device)
    for page in pdfpage.PDFPage.create_pages(document):
        interpreter.process_page(page)
        results = device.get_result()
        elements = [
            element for element in results if isinstance(element, LTTextContainer)
        ]
device.close()

print(elements)
```

items.title: Centered text on different lines don't get grouped into text boxes
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

[Example PDF here](https://www.dropbox.com/s/iesuryj5ter1bax/centered_text_example.pdf?dl=0)

When extracting text from the example PDF (example code below), you can see that "Text 1" and "Text 2" are grouped into one text box, "Text 3" and "Text 4" are getting grouped into another, but "Long Text 1" is not.

If the text was left-justified or right-justified, they would all get merged into one text box.

**Why does this happen?**
This happens because of the [find_neighbors](https://github.com/pdfminer/pdfminer.six/blob/develop/pdfminer/layout.py#L418) function

In particular, you can see that lines which are within the line margin (the `plane.find` bit) are considered for grouping. They are grouped if the lines are a similar height (`abs(obj.height-self.height) < d`), and if either the left end of the text is in a similar place, i.e. the text is left-justified (`abs(obj.x0-self.x0) < d`), or if the text is right-justified (`abs(obj.x1-self.x1) < d`).

**Describe the solution you'd like**

It might make sense for centered text to become grouped too.

This could be achieved by adding an additional check to see if the center of the elements are aligned, something like `abs((obj.x0 + obj.x1)/2 - (self.x0 + self.x1)/2) < d`.

I'd be very happy to PR a fix for this, but thought I'd check it was something you'd like first.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
None.

**Additional notes**

- It feels a bit strange to me that `d = ratio*self.height` where `ratio=laparams.line_margin` is being used as a measure of how close things on the `x` axis need to be. Could this be explained? My current guess is that it's simply to avoid needing a new parameter?

- The above is all posed in relation to horizontal lines, but the equivalent change would be made to the vertical case.

**Example code**
```
from pdfminer import converter, pdfdocument, pdfinterp, pdfpage, pdfparser
from pdfminer.layout import LTTextContainer, LAParams
path_to_file = "centered_text_example.pdf"

with open(path_to_file, "rb") as pdf_file:
    parser = pdfparser.PDFParser(pdf_file)
    document = pdfdocument.PDFDocument(parser)
    resource_manager = pdfinterp.PDFResourceManager()
    device = converter.PDFPageAggregator(resource_manager, laparams=LAParams())
    interpreter = pdfinterp.PDFPageInterpreter(resource_manager, device)
    for page in pdfpage.PDFPage.create_pages(document):
        interpreter.process_page(page)
        results = device.get_result()
        elements = [
            element for element in results if isinstance(element, LTTextContainer)
        ]
device.close()

print(elements)
```

**To Reproduce**

2. Download [PDF](https://www.icann.org/en/system/files/files/participating-08nov13-en.pdf)

items.title: Make configurable the amount of intermediate spaces to be inserted to separate words in line
items.body:
### Current functionality

> If characters are on the same line but not part of the same word, an intermediate space is inserted.
[https://pdfminersix.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/composable.html#laparams](url)

### What is the issue with current functionality
If words themself contain spaces (e.g. number contains space as a decimal separator ) then when such PDF file is converted to text, it becomes difficult to separate different words (e.g. numbers) from each other 

### What is desired improvement
Make configurable the amount of intermediate spaces to be inserted to separate words in line (with the default equal to 1)

items.title: pdf2txt.py -t xml not extracting all information for extended encoding?
items.body:
I'm trying to get the text out this mixed Arabic-English document: 

https://www.dropbox.com/s/rfoisx2bw651l08/a.pdf?dl=0

A command like 'pdf2txt.py -t xml -p 22 a.pdf' gets all the English text information.

For the Arabic text, it seems it uses different embedded fonts/font-size combinations to render it, but I don't think I get all the information I need to reconstruct the Arabic. The number of characters seems roughly OK, but there simply is not enough variety in the values, as many of them map to colons or periods.

This suggests to me that there's some non-ascii encoding going on, and that pdf2txt somehow truncates to the most significant bits.

Could this be the case? If so, how could I get all the raw info out of the pdf, so that I can continue analysing it and mapping the characters to the correct unicode?

items.title: Getting an error in Python 3.x version 3.7-Getting ImportError: cannot import name 'PDFDocument'
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
from pdfminer.pdfparser import PDFParser, PDFDocument
Getting ImportError: cannot import name 'PDFDocument' from 'pdfminer.pdfparser'
**To Reproduce**
Try any Python 3x version with below line ,
from pdfminer.pdfparser import PDFParser, PDFDocument

Code:

from io import StringIO
from pdfminer.pdfparser import PDFParser, PDFDocument
from pdfminer.pdfinterp import PDFResourceManager
from pdfminer.pdfinterp import PDFPageInterpreter as PI
from pdfminer.pdfdevice import PDFDevice
from pdfminer.converter import TextConverter

import utils

__all__ = ['PDF']

class PDFPageInterpreter(PI):
    def process_page(self, page):
        if 1 <= self.debug:
            print >>stderr, 'Processing page: %r' % page
        (x0,y0,x1,y1) = page.mediabox
        if page.rotate == 90:
            ctm = (0,-1,1,0, -y0,x1)
        elif page.rotate == 180:
            ctm = (-1,0,0,-1, x1,y1)
        elif page.rotate == 270:
            ctm = (0,1,-1,0, y1,-x0)
        else:
            ctm = (1,0,0,1, -x0,-y0)
        self.device.outfp.seek(0)
        self.device.outfp.buf = ''
        self.device.begin_page(page, ctm)
        self.render_contents(page.resources, page.contents, ctm=ctm)
        self.device.end_page(page)
        return self.device.outfp.getvalue()

class PDF(list):
    def __init__(self,file, password='', just_text=1):
        self.parser = PDFParser(file)
        self.doc = PDFDocument()
        self.parser.set_document(self.doc)
        self.doc.set_parser(self.parser)
        self.doc.initialize(password)
        if self.doc.is_extractable:
            self.resmgr = PDFResourceManager()
            self.device = TextConverter(self.resmgr, outfp=StringIO())
            self.interpreter = PDFPageInterpreter(
               self.resmgr, self.device)
            for page in self.doc.get_pages():
                self.append(self.interpreter.process_page(page))
            self.metadata = self.doc.info
        if just_text:
            self._cleanup()

    def _cleanup(self):
        """ 
        Frees lots of non-textual information, such as the fonts
        and images and the objects that were needed to parse the
        PDF.
        """
        del self.device
        del self.doc
        del self.parser
        del self.resmgr
        del self.interpreter

    def text(self, clean=True):
        """ 
        Returns the text of the PDF as a single string.
        Options:
          :clean:
            Removes misc cruft, like lots of whitespace.
        """
        if clean:
            return ''.join(utils.trim_whitespace(page) for page in self)
        else:
            return ''.join(self) 

Also getting - ImportError: cannot import name 'PDFDocument' 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Another code also getting same error 
from pdfminer.pdfparser import PDFParser, PDFDocument
from pdfminer.pdfinterp import PDFResourceManager, PDFPageInterpreter
from pdfminer.converter import PDFPageAggregator
from pdfminer.layout import LAParams, LTTextBox, LTTextLine

doc = PDFDocument()

doc.set_parser(parser)

rsrcmgr = PDFResourceManager()

device = PDFPageAggregator(rsrcmgr, laparams=laparams)
interpreter = PDFPageInterpreter(rsrcmgr, device)
# Process each page contained in the document.
for page in doc.get_pages():
    interpreter.process_page(page)
    layout = device.get_result()
    for lt_obj in layout:
        if isinstance(lt_obj, LTTextBox) or isinstance(lt_obj, LTTextLine):
            print(lt_obj.get_text())

fp.close()

 ImportError : cannot import name 'PDFDocument'

**Expected behavior**
Should not getting ImportError : cannot import name 'PDFDocument'

All Python 3x version getting this error -  ImportError : cannot import name 'PDFDocument'
Also  previous code Python 2x version code need to replace from "from cStringIO import StringIO"  to "from io import StringIO".

items.title: Added text colors to the loose html conversion
items.body: I was surprised to find that the html text had no colors after conversion. I made a patch to take the colors from the pdf and add them to the loose html conversion. ```diff diff --git a/pdfminer/converter.py b/pdfminer/converter.py index eaf0520..2087f40 100644 --- a/pdfminer/converter.py +++ b/pdfminer/converter.py @@ -346,13 +346,24 @@ class HTMLConverter(PDFConverter): self.write('') return - def put_text(self, text, fontname, fontsize): + def cmyk_to_rgb(self, cmyk): + r = 255*(1.0-(cmyk[0]+cmyk[3])) + g = 255*(1.0-(cmyk[1]+cmyk[3])) + b = 255*(1.0-(cmyk[2]+cmyk[3])) + return r,g,b + + def put_text(self, text, fontname, fontsize, textcolor): font = (fontname, fontsize) if font != self._font: if self._font is not None: self.write('') - self.write('' % - (enc(fontname), fontsize * self.scale * self.fontscale)) + htmlcolor = "" + if len(textcolor) == 4: + textcolor = self.cmyk_to_rgb(textcolor) + if len(textcolor) == 3: + htmlcolor = 'color: rgb(%s,%s,%s)'%(textcolor[0], textcolor[1], textcolor[2]) + self.write('' % + (enc(fontname), fontsize * self.scale * self.fontscale, htmlcolor)) self._font = font self.write_text(text) return @@ -418,7 +429,7 @@ class HTMLConverter(PDFConverter): render(child) self.end_div('textbox') elif isinstance(item, LTChar): - self.put_text(item.get_text(), item.fontname, item.size) + self.put_text(item.get_text(), item.fontname, item.size, item.graphicstate.ncolor) elif isinstance(item, LTText): self.write_text(item.get_text()) return ```

items.title: Version pdfminer.six 20191107 incorrectly orders some text
items.body:
Upgrading from version 20181108 to 20191107 pdfminer parses some words out of order.
In version 20181108 the ordering was correct, see first output below.
In version 20191107 the ordering is incorrect, see second output below.

In this pdf: http://unec.edu.az/application/uploads/2014/12/pdf-sample.pdf

The fourth bullet point ends with the word "anyone".  When parsing, "anyone" now ends up at the end of the third bullet point instead (directly following "incompatibilities").

Sample parsing logic:
```
import os
import sys
from io import StringIO
from pprint import pprint

from pdfminer.pdfparser import PDFParser
from pdfminer.pdfdocument import PDFDocument
from pdfminer.pdfpage import PDFPage, PDFTextExtractionNotAllowed
from pdfminer.pdfinterp import PDFResourceManager, PDFPageInterpreter
from pdfminer.layout import LAParams
from pdfminer.converter import TextConverter

def get_text(path):
    fd = open(path, 'rb')

    parser = PDFParser(fd)
    document = PDFDocument(parser)

    # Try to parse the document
    if not document.is_extractable:
        raise PDFTextExtractionNotAllowed

    rsrcmgr = PDFResourceManager()

    text = StringIO()

    device = TextConverter(rsrcmgr, text, codec='utf-8', laparams=LAParams())

    interpreter = PDFPageInterpreter(rsrcmgr, device)

    for page in PDFPage.create_pages(document):
        interpreter.process_page(page)

    return text.getvalue()

txt = get_text(os.path.abspath(sys.argv[1]))
pprint(txt)
```

items.title: Create function that returns the extracted text

Currently, you need to use an file-like output argument to get the text from a pdf. For example: 

```python
from io import StringIO
output_string = StringIO()
with open('samples/simple1.pdf', 'rb') as fin:
     extract_text_to_fp(fin, output_string)

Having to use an output-argument is annoying since most people just want to do:

```python
text = pdf_to_text('samples/simple1.pdf')
```

**Describe the case**

In the tools directory are some files that are not needed for pdfminer.six, a package for getting text out of a pdf:

- `*.spec` files - I think these are used for [PyInstaller](https://pythonhosted.org/PyInstaller/spec-files.html). PyInstaller can package a Python application will all its executables. I think it creates something of a .exe file (on windows). 

    I think we should drop those files. This project is about extracting text from pdfs. If someone wants to package pdfminer.six and run it without having Python installed they can do it anyway. We don't need to facilitate that. Also, I doubt if anybody usage this but that might just be because I'm not familiar with these spec files. 

- `*.cgi` files - I think these have something to do with a webinterface, or [common gateway interfaces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Gateway_Interface).

    Like the .spec files, I am convinced that we should not facilitate using pdfminer.six in a webinterface. This package should do one thing and do it well.

items.title: Debug flag for pdf2text.py and dumpdf.py does not change anything
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

Using the debug flag (`-d` or `--debug`) with pdf2txt.py or dumppdf.py does not change anything to the log statements. In pdf2txt.py the debug variable is never used. In dumppdf.py the flag is used to do `logging.getLogger().setLevel(logging.DEBUG)` but this only has an effect if `logging.basicConfig()` is called before (see [here](https://stackoverflow.com/a/38537983/4054971)), which is not the case.

**Expected behavior**

Using the `-d` or `--debug` flag should show all debug logs.

items.title: Use code-style enforcement
items.body:
A lot of files in this project don't follow [PEP8](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/). 

I would like to have some code-style enforcement in this project because (for me) it makes the code more readable and maintainable. 

I've earlier worded with [flake8](https://flake8.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq.html) and think it works really well. 

Also see this earlier (closed) PR: https://github.com/pdfminer/pdfminer.six/pull/92.

items.title: how to program with pdfminer.six
items.body:
i have been programming with pdfminer3k because there are some examples in the internet
but for somg reason i need CJK support so i install pdfminer.six
i found there are all command functions 
is there any coding sample that programming with pdfminer.six?
attatch my code in pdfminer3k
```python
from pdfminer.pdfparser import PDFParser,PDFDocument
from pdfminer.pdfinterp import PDFResourceManager, PDFPageInterpreter
from pdfminer.converter import PDFPageAggregator
from pdfminer.layout import LTTextBoxHorizontal,LAParams,LTFigure
from pdfminer.pdfinterp import PDFTextExtractionNotAllowed
def get_mulu_text1(pdf_path):
    fp = open(pdf_path, 'rb')  

    praser = PDFParser(fp)

    doc = PDFDocument()

    praser.set_document(doc)
    doc.set_parser(praser)

    doc.initialize()

    if not doc.is_extractable:
        raise PDFTextExtractionNotAllowed
    else:
        rsrcmgr = PDFResourceManager()
        laparams = LAParams()
        device = PDFPageAggregator(rsrcmgr, laparams=laparams)
        interpreter = PDFPageInterpreter(rsrcmgr, device)
        for page in doc.get_pages():  # doc.get_pages() 获取page列表
            interpreter.process_page(page)
            layout = device.get_result()
            if (layout.pageid <10):
                for x in layout:
                    if (isinstance(x, LTTextBoxHorizontal)):
                        results = x.get_text()
                        print(results)
                        print('-')
            else:
                break
```

above codes seems work in pdfminer3k,but not work in pdfminer.six because of some library changed name or other reasons

items.body:
That's actually an issue on the original repo ([as seen here](https://github.com/euske/pdfminer/issues/162)) that I stumbled upon. A PR with a fix also exists [here](https://github.com/euske/pdfminer/pull/185). 

Should I recreate that PR in here?

EDIT - original issue message by @jeresch for the sake of better organization:

When parsing a document, I am getting an exception with the following traceback:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./main.py", line 748, in parseEachProfile
    self.people.append(parser.parse(None))
  File "./main.py", line 322, in parse
    poslist = parser.parsepdf2(filename)
  File "/Users/____/Dropbox/___/Parser/pdfparsing.py", line 167, in parsepdf2
    interpreter.process_page(page)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pdfminer/pdfinterp.py", line 839, in process_page
    self.render_contents(page.resources, page.contents, ctm=ctm)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pdfminer/pdfinterp.py", line 852, in render_contents
    self.execute(list_value(streams))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pdfminer/pdfinterp.py", line 877, in execute
    func(*args)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pdfminer/pdfinterp.py", line 760, in do_TJ
    self.device.render_string(self.textstate, seq)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pdfminer/pdfdevice.py", line 82, in render_string
    scaling, charspace, wordspace, rise, dxscale)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pdfminer/pdfdevice.py", line 98, in render_string_horizontal
    font, fontsize, scaling, rise, cid)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pdfminer/converter.py", line 112, in render_char
    textwidth = font.char_width(cid)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pdfminer/pdffont.py", line 517, in char_width
    return self.widths[cid] * self.hscale
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for *: 'PDFObjRef' and 'float'
```

On closer inspection with pdb, I saw an issue:

```
(Pdb) p self.widths
{0: 1000, 1: 277, 2: 333, 3: 666, 4: 556, 5: 556, 6: 556, 7: <PDFObjRef:11>, 8: 333, 9: 943, 10: 556, 11: 556, 12: 777, 13: 556, 14: 722, 15: 556, 16: 277, 17: <PDFObjRef:11>, 18: 277, 19: 222, 20: 222, 21: 277, 22: 666, 23: 610, 24: <PDFObjRef:11>, 25: 556, 26: 556, 27: 556, 28: 833, 29: 666, 30: <PDFObjRef:11>, 31: <PDFObjRef:11>, 32: 666, 33: 777, 34: 556, 35: 556, 36: 556, 37: 556, 38: 556, 39: 666, 40: 333, 41: 556, 42: 333, 43: <PDFObjRef:11>, 44: 556, 45: 583, 46: 556, 47: 722, 48: 277, 49: <PDFObjRef:11>, 50: 833, 51: 556, 52: 610, 53: 556, 54: 666, 55: 722, 56: 222, 57: <PDFObjRef:11>, 58: 277, 59: 722, 60: 222, 61: 277}
```

When the exception occurred, cid was 7, self.hscale was 0.001, and as shown above, self.widths[7] is not a float, but a PDFObjRef. On probing the object, I got

```
(Pdb) p self.widths[7].__dict__
{'doc': <pdfminer.pdfdocument.PDFDocument object at 0x10d23d310>, 'objid': 11}
```

I tried stepping through with pdb, but wasn't quite able to figure out where the PDFObjRef got inserted. In pdffont.py, there are two functions that seem likely: get_width(seq) and get_width2(seq), but this depends on the input obviously.

I can provide the problematic pdf if anyone would find it useful. I'll have to go through and scrub confidential information though, so I'll hold off for now. -Jeremy

items.title: name2unicode() does not conform to the Adobe Glyph List Specification
items.body:
Earlier issues (#183, #229) mention that the `name2unicode()` function does not handle hexadecimal literals well. These issues are solved by changing the regex that matches the hexadecimal literals. 

However, the functionality of `name2unicode()` still does not match the [mapping in the spec](https://github.com/adobe-type-tools/agl-specification#2-the-mapping). 

The spec also lists a couple of [examples](https://github.com/adobe-type-tools/agl-specification#3-examples) that could serve as unittests and would fail now.

I suggest we follow the spec, with the exception of specific mapping for Zapf Dingbats.

items.title: Describe how to behave as a contributor
items.body:
I think it would help future contributors to participate if it is clear what we expect from them and what they can expect from the project. I'm thinking of the following:

- Use issues to point to problems
    - Discuss possible improvements in an issue
    - Include a minimal reproducible example if possible
    - Include the package version
- Use pull requests to fix problems
    - So no PR without an issue
    - Point your PR to the develop branch
    - PR's should be PEP8 compliant
    - PR's should create or update PEP257 docstrings if necessary. 
    - PR's should include testing of the minimal reproducing examle if possible
    - PR's should work with python2 and python3 (for now)
    - PR's should succesfully run test-suite (on travis)

Also, when using dir on a pdfminer.layout.LTImage object, dir yields a different list depending on whether or not I call it from the library, or from a real object extracted from a document and identified as an instance of LTImage by isintance, and by type(object) (below are respective lists, pruned for primitive methods and attributes):
